results.title: Boris Johnson Pledges Transformed Economy for U.K.
results.abstract: The prime minister sketched a vision of Britain on the cusp of change, but barely mentioned the spate of fuel and food shortages that have afflicted the country in recent weeks.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, speaking at his Conservative Party’s annual conference, said Britain would break from an economic model of “low wages, low growth, low skills.”
Prime Minister Boris Johnson, speaking at his Conservative Party’s annual conference, said Britain would break from an economic model of “low wages, low growth, low skills.”

results.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Awarded to Scientists for Creating a Tool to Build Molecules
results.abstract: Benjamin List and David W.C. MacMillan were honored for work that spurred research into new drugs and reduced the effect of chemistry on the environment.
results.byline: By Marc Santora and Cora Engelbrecht

multimedia.caption: The Nobel committee announcing the chemistry prize in Stockholm on Wednesday. The scientists honored, Benjamin List and David W.C. MacMillan, discovered a new type of catalysis.
The Nobel committee announcing the chemistry prize in Stockholm on Wednesday. The scientists honored, Benjamin List and David W.C. MacMillan, discovered a new type of catalysis.

results.title: A Sea of White Faces in Australia’s ‘Party of Multiculturalism’
results.abstract: A young daughter of Vietnamese refugees was set to run for Parliament. Then she was passed over for a white insider, and a debate over cultural diversity flared into the open.

multimedia.caption: Tu Le in Cabramatta, a suburb of Sydney, on Thursday. She had been set to become the opposition Labor Party’s candidate for Parliament in one of Sydney’s most diverse districts.
multimedia.copyright: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

results.title: Vatican Issues Acquittals in Sexual Abuse Case Involving Ex-Seminarians
results.abstract: One defendant, now a priest, had been accused of sexual abuse when he and his accuser were teenagers at a seminary within the Vatican walls. Another priest was accused of covering it up.

multimedia.caption: St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City in 2020. Both defendants had denied any wrongdoing and said that their accuser had been motivated by a personal vendetta against them.
St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City in 2020. Both defendants had denied any wrongdoing and said that their accuser had been motivated by a personal vendetta against them.

results.title: Behind the Global Appeal of ‘Squid Game,’ a Country’s Economic Unease
results.abstract: The dystopian Netflix hit taps South Korea’s worries about costly housing and scarce jobs, concerns familiar to its U.S. and international viewers.

results.title: Germany Sets Aside an Additional $767 Million for Holocaust Survivors, Officials Say
results.abstract: Many of those now eligible for reparations are Russian Jews who survived the Nazi siege of Leningrad. They will receive annual pensions of about $5,200, or 4,500 euros.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany

multimedia.caption: Members of historical military clubs in January 2020 celebrating the 76th anniversary of the full liberation of Leningrad from the Nazi blockade in World War II in St. Petersburg, Russia.

results.title: English Schools Drop Mask Mandates, but Questions Rise Along With Cases
results.abstract: England is taking more risks than many U.S. schools as a way of returning to normal. Many parents approve, but with more than 180,000 students absent in recent weeks, others question the trade off.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Megan Specia

multimedia.caption: Social-distancing signs on the floors of Copley Academy in Stalybridge, England, last month as students returned to school.

results.title: A Tech-Savvy Holocaust Memorial in Ukraine Draws Critics and Crowds
results.abstract: Traditionalists chafe at the contemporary-art approach to Holocaust commemoration being employed at Babyn Yar, a site of mass shootings in World War II. But it has brought visitors for an anniversary.

des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center (Kyiv, Ukraine)

results.title: After Pastor Evicts Nearly 200 Migrants, His Brother Welcomes Them All
results.abstract: An evangelical minister in a Mexico border town had let dozens of migrant families live in his church. When he ousted most of them, his brother across the way invited the outcasts into his home.

results.abstract: A father and son have been held in Iran while three U.S. presidents occupied the White House. Now the father faces a dire medical emergency and his family is pleading for his release.

results.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: A young fan of “The Battle at Lake Changjin” on Saturday in Wuhan, China. The film, which opened this month, is on pace to be among the country’s most successful.

results.title: Captured, Killed or Compromised: C.I.A. Admits to Losing Dozens of Informants
results.abstract: Counterintelligence officials said in a top secret cable to all stations and bases around the world that too many of the people it recruits from other countries to spy for the U.S. are being lost.
results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman

multimedia.caption: Members of the Taliban at the former C.I.A. Eagle Base in Kabul in September. The agency has devoted much of its attention for the last two decades to terrorist threats and the conflicts in Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria, but improving intelligence collection on adversaries like China and Russia is once again a centerpiece of its agenda.

results.title: A Debt-Ceiling Showdown
results.abstract: Nobody seems to know how it will be resolved.

results.title: Nobel Prize in Physics Awarded for Study of Humanity’s Role in Changing Climate
results.abstract: The work of Syukuro Manabe, Klaus Hasselmann and Giorgio Parisi “demonstrate that our knowledge about the climate rests on a solid scientific foundation,” the committee said.
results.byline: By Cade Metz, Marc Santora and Cora Engelbrecht

multimedia.caption: Syukuro Manabe of Princeton University, Klaus Hasselmann of the Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg, Germany, and Giorgio Parisi of the Sapienza University of Rome were awarded the prize in Physics in Stockholm on Tuesday.

Syukuro Manabe of Princeton University, Klaus Hasselmann of the Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg, Germany, and Giorgio Parisi of the Sapienza University of Rome were awarded the prize in Physics in Stockholm on Tuesday.

results.title: Indonesia plans to allow foreign flights into Bali as early as next week.
results.abstract: Bali is Indonesia’s most important tourist destination, and closing the island to foreign tourists has devastated the tourism industry.
results.byline: By Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat

multimedia.caption: At the international departures area of Ngurah Rai airport on the Indonesian island of Bali on Tuesday.
At the international departures area of Ngurah Rai airport on the Indonesian island of Bali on Tuesday.

results.title: Australia and New Zealand inch closer to fully reopening their economies.
results.abstract: Australia’s prime minister gave more detail on the timeline for reopening to travelers, while New Zealand’s announced plans for a vaccine pass program.
results.byline: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Natasha Frost

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia during a news conference on Friday. The country could let foreign tourists return next year, he has said.

results.title: Facebook’s Apps Went Down. The World Saw How Much It Runs on Them.
results.abstract: The outage disrupted the digital lives of small-business owners, politicians, aid workers and others. But for some, it was a welcome reprieve.
results.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Adam Satariano

multimedia.caption: A woman checking her Instagram account in New York City on Monday. Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger have long been more than handy tools for chatting and sharing photos.

results.title: Over 200,000 Minors Abused by Clergy in France Since 1950, Report Estimates
results.abstract: An independent commission set up at the request of the Roman Catholic Church in France found that abuse was far more pervasive than previously thought.

multimedia.caption: Easter celebrations at a church in Paris this year. The report released Tuesday was the most extensive account to date of the scope of sexual abuse by clergy in France, especially against children and vulnerable people.

results.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
results.abstract: A lengthy outage shakes Facebook and its apps.

multimedia.caption: Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., last month. The company’s internal communications platform, Workplace, was also taken out, leaving most employees unable to do their jobs.
